Here's additional information about preparations in case SPFE and its bargaining groups go on strike on Tuesday, March 10. If the strike takes place, all PreK-12 schools and ECSE classes and services will be closed beginning that day.

▪️ Breakfast 8:30-9:30 a.m.
▪️ Lunch 11 a.m.- 12:30 p.m.

Please read this very important information about a possible teacher strike that would impact your family and every family in SPPS.

Since May SPPS has been negotiating a new employment contract with the Saint Paul Federation of Educators (SPFE) union. Mediation will continue through the weekend.

If SPPS and SPFE are unable to reach an agreement by the end of Monday, SPFE has announced it will call a strike beginning Tuesday, March 10. This means SPFE members will not report to work until the two parties reach an agreement on a new contract.

The SPPS Board of Education and administrative staff are developing plans to help care for your children in case a strike takes place. We are able to give you an overview now, and we ask you to watch your email, social media, spps.org/negotiations and other information sources closely in the coming days for additional details.

Question: What’s the best part of your job?

Answer: There are so many amazing things about being a teacher that it is hard to narrow it down to just one thing. One of the best parts is seeing students achieve at levels that they previously didn't think they could. Of course, that is a different spot for nearly every single student. Students can easily see who is genuinely willing to help them grow into young adults, rather than just improve a test score. On a daily basis, it's often hard to know if you are really making an impact. When students swing by your classroom just to say hi, send an email or a handwritten letter or card or stop by just to see how you are doing and what my current classes are studying, it provides me with extra inspiration and really motivates me to want to improve my teaching.

Question: What’s the best part of your job?
Answer: The best part of my job is working with my EL students in groups and watching them as they grasp a concept, such as using compare/contrast language in their writing. It’s especially inspiring when they can relay what they just learned to another EL student. It’s so exciting when our new-to-country students produce language for the first time, seeing how proud and accomplished they feel. Another great part of my job is collaborating with colleagues who willingly share their expertise and welcome me into their classrooms.

Also, I believe the Parent Teacher Home Visit Project is one of the best initiatives to come out of our district in a long time. We get to visit with our students and families in their home environment, where the focus is not necessarily on academics but rather on the hopes and dreams they have for their children.

Patricia Boyt is an EL teacher at Eastern Heights Elementary. She is a candidate for the 2020 Minnesota Teacher of the Year award.

post_text: SPPS students, staff and community members turned out to celebrate the start of construction on the Midway Peace Park near Gordon Parks High School. The idea for the park began more than five years ago when Gordon Parks students recognized the need for green space in their neighborhood. Working with the City of Saint Paul and The Trust for Public Land, students gathered community input and helped in the park's design. When completed next spring, the park will benefit the high school, local businesses and more than 800 low-income, new immigrant residents from Skyline Tower. The park is part of the Cities' long-term vision to create vibrant outdoor gathering spaces that strengthen community connections along the Green Line.

post_text: This summer, Central Senior High School teacher Stephanie McCleerey had the opportunity of a lifetime when she traveled to Washington D.C to witness the U.S. Supreme Court in action. Through 'Street Law', a nonprofit organization that educates young people about law and government, she participated in the Supreme Court Institute for Teachers. The institute brings a select group of high school social studies teachers to Washington, for an immersive six days of educational activities related to teaching about the Court. McCleerey was one of 60 teachers chosen nationwide to participate in the program. She is excited to incorporate what she learned this summer into her classroom.

post_text: Students arriving at E-STEM Middle School were captivated by the building’s modern and open design as they walked through the doors on the first day of school. Situated on the Saint Paul-Woodbury border, E-STEM offers students opportunities to focus on Science, Technology, Engineering and Math – all through environmental education. A nearby pond and hiking trail serve as an extension of the classroom where students can put what they learn into practice. E-STEM staff use technology to help students communicate with math as the language, and science and engineering as the process for developing critical thinking skills. For the 2019-20 school year, the school will serve grade 6 with expansion to grades 7 and 8 in subsequent years.
